they must be stimulated the imagination must be triggered by what they see and they engage with and of course escap R

that sort of gave me my list of requirements that I wanted I wanted the escape room to have simple puzzles and
when I say simple I don't mean easy simple just means they must be easy for the children to understand because I

them multiple times now out of all of these requirements the hardest one to achieve from for me was the finishable
specifically within that 45 to 60 Minute window and the reason for this is that
some children are really really smart they are absolutely gifted and some
children are they haven't grown into their smartness
yet um and designing an escape room for different types of children with different skill sets and different
strengths so that they're all finished within that 45 minute to 60 Minute window is really difficult so what I
eventually came up with is I needed a way to be able to take the difficulty of the puzzles in my escape room and change

wanted to make the puzzles later on a little bit easier but of course I didn't want the children to know I was doing

children so let's take a look at some of the puzzles that I made um and how we can use those puzzles or change those

this puzzle to have it that if you point it at specific targets um it triggers a
success so you could have numbers stuck up around the wall of the room and if they pointed at the nine then the four
then the two the com combination could be 942 for them now the way I can change
the difficulty of this puzzle is by changing how close it must be to the Target how perfectly flat must it
be how long must it be on the target before it registers a success and the
number of targets that you must use so obviously this wouldn't work if you were using it to um show a combination like
932 but if you had it that they had to point it at the Sun the moon and then the window you could decrease the number

you can change the difficulty of this by changing the length of the song Mary Had a Little Lamb is easier than Mary had a

red gray red yellow blue uh yellow red and the lights will flash across the
different devices and the children have to repeat that same combination by pushing the buttons on each device
children have no chill with this and as soon as someone got it wrong there was amazing fights and screaming between

with so there were five that I that I eventually made to make it easier you could reduce the number of devices that

so a sword that's kept in place with a maglock on the side and as soon as the maglock releases they can take the sword
out and see whatever was on the side there I can tell you my wife really loved this
one but she didn't love it nearly as much as I love the next one this is I think the best way to dispense Clues I
call it splinters in danger and again uh my wife says that I've got
a very uh prototype aesthetic I think she's been very kind cuz this looks like  there's a little server motor at
the bottom of the latch and it keeps a string under tension and when the server motor releases it flips forward and it
hits the plank in front shooting off whatever you've put in the little Contraption at the top this is really

the musical tone before where everyone's listening very intently and they're trying to solve the thing and suddenly
bam it gives them a great fright and this thing comes flying through the air I like to think that by terrifying the
children I'm teaching them that progress is scary and achieving your goals is something that they shouldn't work too
hard towards so all of these devices have something in common and that's how I interact with them I use ESP this is an
ESP 8266 uh most of the devices I used esp32s some of them a266 you don't
really have to know too much about the difference ultimately what these are are these are little programable computers
like uh arduinos with Wi-Fi and you can turn them into portable web servers so you can have some code that runs there
and says well when I get an HTTP request on this uh endpoint return this response
or do something like that so you could send a request through that says well uh when I send uh you can make a HTTP
request to the device that will then cause the device to open the mag lock for instance the problem with this is
that the way that this works is that there's a server. handle client method so this little Loop method gets called
over and over and over and over and over again and the server. handle client just goes and checks well do I have any
waiting HTTP requests that I need to respond to and this is single threaded
which means that in the happy path what happens is you get an HTTP request into the device and the device says oh okay
sure here's your response but it's not always going to work like that because sometimes you
might have other devices connected so this is a digital spirit level it's an mpu 6050 you don't really need to know
about that but some of these devices have digital motion processing on the chip and some of them don't and if they
don't have it on the chip you have to do that calculation yourself manually so if your device is busy calculating the
angle it might take a long time and if it's taken a long time and you get an HTTP request coming into that device
wireless busy calculating the angle by the time it manages to work out what the response is and finish in the angle that
HTTP request could have timed out and as far as the client is concerned that device is no longer
working this is a form of temporal coupling where you've got if you make the request at the right time you'll get
the response but if you make the request at the wrong time you might not so ideally instead of having this
type of coupling the better way to do it would be you'd have your devices sitting there they would calculate the angle for
whatever they need to do they would take whatever time they have to do to calculate that angle um they would get the response and then
afterwards they would go and check well what do I need to do next maybe there's a database somewhere that's got a list
of things that they have to do oh I've got the angle here the angle is this so now I need to go and open that mag lock
or something now because I work for a particular software we do a lot of messaging so naturally I went for mqtt
which is a messaging technology stands for message Q transient Telemetry I think um and it's a really nice way of
of using messaging with these iot devices because it's lightweight um so these low power devices can work quite
easily within with mqtt it's reliable so you can specify three different levels
of quality of service you can do um at most once delivery at least once delivery and exactly once delivery which
is pretty cool it's also standards based so if you're working with a mqtt broker and one day you want to move to I don't
know as your iot event hubs you can just change and everything should work in theory because it is standards based but
even though got the word q in the name it's not actually a q so there's a few downsides here um the Q length of mqtt
can only be zero or one you can't ever have more messages in a queue which is
weird for a queue um and it's got a slightly smaller feature set but we'll take a look a little bit later at how we can work
around this so for my system I had all of these devices and they were communicate communicating via mosquito
mosquito is an instance of mqtt and that's all of the context out of the way so now we're going to start
getting into the microservice stuff and the things we're going to look at are how to how I monitored it um how I
decided what the aggregate roots are for these different components how I managed the flow of the scate how I was able to
change the difficulty of the puzzles as people were playing and how to work around the limitations of
mqtt so those are the four things we're going to cover in the rest of this talk monitoring the devices so the first
thing that I did when I moned the devices is I wanted to know about failures when something goes wrong I want to know about it but the thing with
these devices is that they're not really that good at this so what happens is if something goes wrong yes you can write
C++ or python or JavaScript on these devices and they all have TR catch mechanisms in them but a lot of the
times the libraries that you use don't really follow good citizenship when it comes to how to deal with exceptions so
often times the devices just crash and reset and when the device comes online you need to go and check well okay why
are you coming online did you lose hour was it a watchdog timer that you thought I was taking too long to do something so
you just reset was it a hardware fault what was it an exception so you need to monitor all of these things so then I
thought okay well what I'll do is instead of actually going and checking the failures I'll just see if the devices are online so I'll include some
type of health check API and I can do that because it's just a web service I'll have a/ API heartbeat and as soon
as it gets a request it just returns a response 200 okay I mean that's fine that works
um I also thought well maybe I could look at the Q length and as I started getting down the the rabbit hole of this it kind of became familiar to me there
was a bit of nostalgia to this and I thought hm hold on this is reminding me
of the way I used the monitor systems in the mid 2000s where you had an application server and a database server
maybe a web server as well if you if you were really fancy and the way you monitor these systems is you just asked
three questions is the web server up is the database up and can the web server
talk to the database server this is a very naive way of monitoring systems and this is kind of what it was feeding like
when I was trying to do these health check apis on these devices because it's basic it's not giving me any
insight but the thing with these devices is they're they're quite small you might even say they're like micro right and
they they provide a service they do some type of capability so maybe they're micro capabilities not microservices
that's a rude word now I know about monitoring distributed systems or microservices because that's
part of my day job and when you monitor distributed systems there's three things you need to think about for everything
that you monitor the first thing that you need to think about is the area that you're monitoring so what do I mean by
the area are you monitoring the infrastructure of your application of your system or are you monitoring the
application of your system or are you monitoring the actual capabilities that your application exposes some example
questions of this is if you're monitoring the infrastructure you might ask well are my devices
online for the application you might ask are my devices responding to Publishers are they doing what they're supposed to
do and for the capability a question might be can my players solve the puzzles that are presented is that
capability functional so when you look at the monitoring area you've got infrastructure application and
capability that you can monitor next to that you've also got the
concern that you're monitoring so by concern what I mean is you could monitor the health of your system now there's a
many to many relationship between the areas and the concerns you can monitor the health of your infrastructure the
health of your application and the health of the capability the same with the performance
you can monitor the performance of your infrastructure the performance of your application and the performance of your
capability and the same with the capacity so those are the three concerns that you could
Monitor and then the third thing with monitoring distri red systems is how you interact with those logs or those
monitor monitoring systems is it passive are you just looking at the log files every now and then or you okay
something's gone wrong we need to look at the open Telemetry for the system and see what went wrong that's passive
you're you're looking at something after the fact you could also do reactive monitoring where maybe the monitoring
system that you've got in place automatically detects oh this looks a little bit weird I'm going to send a push notification to the Ops Team so
that they can look at this before it becomes a potential problem and then you've got proactive monitoring
so this is where the system would try and make changes to fix whatever might be potentially a problem a good example
here is auto scaling if the Q length is getting really long maybe you automatically scale up other instances
of your handlers so that you can bring that Q length down so with this framework in place
let's take a look at what we were seeing with the uh iot devices so with the health check apis what I was monitoring
was the health of my infrastructure and I was doing it passively cuz I would just go and look well something's not
working are they oh yes they're all up it's fine but if I was looking at the mqtt Q
length now because of the mqtt Q length can either only be zero or one I know that if a q length stays one for a
really long time it means that something isn't taking messages off of the queue so again I know that there's something
wrong at an infrastructure level the health of my infrastructure is suffering there if I was looking at the failure is
that would be as soon as the device restarts it goes and sends a message to say hey I failed because X that is a
reactive way of monitoring the infrastructure of the health of my infrastructure now this is a lot of
Health infrastructure monitoring that I was doing am I getting new information from these three things and the answer
is not really because there were times where the health check API was telling me that the devices were up and working
but the mqtt Q length wasn't changing it wasn't ever decreasing and what that tells me is that while the
device is online and it's on the Wi-Fi network and it's responding to http requests it's not taking messages off of
the queue it's not processing messages so the health check was actually a false positive and with that information I
could then say well I don't actually care about the health check API anymore instead what I can rather have is a dashboard or another tool that monitors
all the Q length and then I can immediately know if the devices are actually processing things I could also
included Canary devices so maybe while the players are going through the escape room I could sit and follow them and do
a few decoy devices on the side to make sure that what was happening here what would happen if they did it over there
and if I picked up a problem potentially see maybe I need to turn the device off and on reseted or something like that
that would be proactive monitoring of the capability that my application was
providing let's take a look at some other examples some uh non iot examples
so perhaps if you monitoring Q length in a real application that might be a good way to check the performance of your
infrastructure if the Q length is increasing that means that the performance is potentially not enough
and you need to scale up the end points or if the Q is decreasing or staying constant the performance is
fine processing time processing time is how long it takes for a message to be processed once it gets taken off of the
queue so how long it takes your application to do something with that that's monitoring the performance of your application
but of course messages don't just exist as they've been processed they exist in the que as well so combining Q length
and processing time we can get a metric known as critical time and a critical time says well as soon as I send this
message the critical time of this message is however long it takes until it is processed completely so that means
it includes how long the processing time is as well as how long it spends in Flight in the queue waiting to get
picked up and you can use that to look at the capacity of your application because that's a more important metric
than just Q length Q length doesn't tell you how long things are staying in the queue it just tells you how many things
are in the queue which is potentially may be a problem maybe it's not if the oldest message in your queue is only
there for 10 seconds maybe not a problem but if you've got a q length of five and
the oldest message in the queue has been there for an hour potentially something you need to respond
to you can also use Q length to trigger scaling and in this case you would be doing proactive monitoring of the
performance of your infrastructure like I said it might be better to use a metric like the critical time or the processing time to be able
to do that scaling because you don't always just want to scale a queue that's got a lot of entries in
it so that's how you monitor distributed systems um you take the area the concern
and the interaction type and you can use that to see if you've got duplicate things duplicate bits of information
that you're getting because if you've got a large distributed system there's a lot of monitoring information that is
can be presented at you and you don't necessarily have to pay attention to all of it so by categorizing which of these
attributes you're monitoring and why you can use that to potentially exclude
noise from your monitoring systems and then use that noise when you need to actually dig into what went
wrong so that's monitoring the iot system let's take a look at the aggregate
Roots I like using the musical tone as an example of an aggregate root because it is self-contained it's a box on its
own everything that you need to do is within that box and it's a physical one so for instance all of the logic is
self-contained I can completely change the way that that musical tone puzzle works and is solved nobody else no other
puzzle in the entire escape room needs to know about that the only thing it needs to do is that when the puzzle has
been solved it must publish an event that says hey I've been solved that's all it needs to do that's its only
promise to the outside world the only thing it needs to know from the outside world is when the difficulty changes I
need to change my difficulty either easier or harder depending on what that is so in this case while it's
a physical device the service boundary the aggregate route is very well defined around this uh
device it's not quite so with something like Simon says so with Simon says where there were three boxes or five boxes or
two boxes involved what would happen is if we had another component that would have to change the difficulty of the
puzzle we're not going to go and publish a message to say well we need to change the difficulty to five whatever that
means it sends a message to Mosquito and then the devices go okay um I can't make
that decision on my own I need to know what the other devices in Simon say are doing so I we need to communicate
together to be able to say well what do we do with that difficulty change which means that the boundary of consistency
cannot be at this physical device level it has to include all of them so what we
could do then is we could have a notion of a primary device and the primary device would have secondary devices once
they all start up they would create a peer-to-peer Network between each other and only the primary has to talk to Mosquito or mqtt then when the
difficulty messages come through that difficulty message goes straight to the primary device and the primary device says okay everyone uh we're only using
the left button now and the pattern is going to be me you you you me me you and
the other devices go oh okay cool got it thanks move on if something goes wrong with the
primary device maybe the battery runs flat and it connects well one of the secondary devices can take over create a
peer-to-peer Network between the other devices that are remaining and then subscribe to Mosquito mqtt so in this
case what this means is that the boundary of consistency of these devices the aggregate root that we've got is
around all of them logically there's only one instance of the devices but physically they're deployed in multiple
places and the boundary of consistency has to be around all three of them with
all three of them in place it means that the logic is self-contained even if it is distributed across multiple devices
the logic within the service boundary can change completely all they need to do is publish an event when the puzzle
has been solved And subscribe to an event when the difficulty changes so the service boundaries well defined around
the three of these let's take a look at some more real world real world examples so maybe
we've got a stock service and a user is trying to delete an item from the stock system and it says okay well I want to
delete this item so the stock service will go to the authorization service and say does the user have access to delete this record and the authorization
service will say yes they do go ahead delete the stock service has had to go
outside of its service boundary to ask for information before it can do what it needs to do it means that the logic is
not self-contained within the stock service it also means that the stock service needs input from the user
service to be able to make a decision on what it needs to do the service boundary is here the aggregate route is poorly
defined another example maybe if you're working in the insurance space is anybody doing Insurance maybe you've got
a claims processing system and the claims processing system would ask the payment system hey has the user paid all
of their premiums again it's going outside of its own system to ask for additional
information or maybe you've got an order service and the order service has to ask the stock service hey do we have stock
of this item that I want to actually send to the customer all of these are examples of where you're going outside
of your boundary of consistency and you're asking for additional information so the fix is easy right
well all you do is if you need more information just make your service boundaries bigger right and include all of those new things in your service
boundary except sometimes that is the right answer but ironically a lot of the time you can make smaller service
boundaries and get those boundaries of consistency even easier for instance If instead of a
stock service that handled removing you had a stock removal service that only removal of stock items the only thing
the service does is remove items from the database we don't have to worry about whether the user has the correct
access to use thisis thing because at a at a permission level we can say well if you can publish a message to this topic
You by default have permissions to be able to remove items it becomes an infrastructure concern not a business uh
rule check that we have to follow so if someone can access that particular topic and publish messages to it it means we
don't need to ask does the user have permission and the important thing here is that we're doing something we're not
a something so we're doing the removal of stock items we're not doing stock service stock service isn't a thing it's
a do when users interact with your system they're doing things they are verbing your system not noun
it so in this case the stock removal system only needs to know what it has to know it doesn't need to know anything
outside of just removal it just needs to know okay the user wants to remove this thing great but what if you had slightly
more complex business rules so everyone can delete items from the stock service or everyone can delete stock items but
only if they're below $1,000 in value if it's more than $1,000 you need approval okay well you still have your
stock removal service and when the user removes an item it publishes an event to
the approved stock removal service and that one approves it so if if the item being deleted is less than $11,000 it
automatically approves it otherwise it appears in someone's inbox and they have to then go and approve that again that
service is only approving the removal of stock items by making the service boundaries smaller and narrower it's
easier to get consistency boundaries or boundaries of consistency and the key thing here is

the state of the escape room run is on schedule they solve some puzzles some time passes and and they're still on

can start taking messages and publish them off to say okay now we need to make the room a little bit easier actually

or on schedule so at a conceptual level the the escape room run is a state machine
that does a few things the first is attract how long the players are spending in the entire room not on
specific puzzles although it can and it adjusts the difficulty of the following puzzles based off of how much time
they've spent already and it can change the entire flow of the room so it can completely take some puzzles out and say

mqtt so as we said mqtt is not actually a que and it's got a slightly smaller feature set the things that were
problematic specifically for what I was trying to do was that there's no support for delayed delivery in mqtt so delay
deliveries is where you say I want this message to only be sent or delivered to the endpoint in a month's time for the
escape room it was going to be uh matters of minutes not months um but there was no support for delayed
delivery at all there's also no support for time to be received which means that if you get a message after it's expired
you want to be able to discard that message where mqtt doesn't have support for that out of the box and most
problematically you can't queue up messages and because there's lots of things going on all at once in the
system there's a high probability that a lot of messages will go to my process manager and it will lose messages
because they'll be overwritten by other messages and strangely for something that's so ubiquitous mqtt is
surprisingly hard to monitor which I found a little bit odd what I would have liked is if I could
have all of my devices talking to a broker that they were really good at talking to and I could have my
application logic my complexity talking to broker that it was really good at talking to and then maybe there was
something in the middle that allowed the two to talk to each other and this is where you implement the messaging Bridge
pattern so the messaging Bridge pattern allows you to have different endpoints on different queing Technologies um and
it takes care of shuttling the messages backwards and forwards to where they need to go and the two sides of the
transport don't need to know anything about each other so for instance if I added another service that collected
stats about my catapult that wouldn't have to change any of the code on the devices side all it would do is say okay
well I I want to subscribe to that message in Rabbid mq and the bridge would take care of saying oh that means I need to subscribe on mqtt and forward
messages through it's a super powerful technique U now the way that it works is
that it would take all of your physical end points so it would replace the sword with a logical sword uh the essence of a
sword if you will it would replace a treasure chest with a logical treasure chest and it would go through all of the
devices and change them it would do the same with the application parts and then the
transports would also just be replaced with transport one and transport two so we're dealing with logical things the
bridge is the only one that knows okay transport one is mqtt transport 2 is rabbit mq which means that when my Saga
needs to send a message it publishes an event to a topic on transport 2 the
bridge knows oh hold on that must actually go to the Catapult so takes the message off of rabit mq goes to mqt and
says well how do I how do I transform this logical endpoint into a physical address okay now I send it over there
which also means that you can add additional functionality without changing the previous system so you can
add a new logical sword and when your Saga publishes an event that the sword
is interested in the first one will go via rabbit mq and the second one will go via rabbit mq mqtt to the original
sword this is a super powerful technique for doing things like modernizing leg Legacy applications if you've got a
system that's talking msmq first of all micr commiserations that must be very hard on you second of all if you've got
the concept of or an implementation of a messaging Bridge you can then instead of having to make changes to your msmq
system deploy the bridge and start using newer cooler technology such as AWS sqs
with lambdas and the msmq system doesn't need to know anything about the new technology the new technology doesn't
